Title: Legend Diane Keaton's Friend Shares Heartbreaking Detail From Final Visit
Description:
Diane Keaton's friend detailed what it was like to see the actress before her tragic passing at the age of 79.

In an interview with PEOPLE, Grammy and Oscar-winning songwriter Carole Bayer Sager spoke about her final visit with Keaton. 

‚ÄúI saw her two or three weeks ago, and she was very thin,‚Äù Sager says. ‚ÄúShe had lost so much weight.‚Äù

Sager also detailed how she hadn't seen too much of Keaton this past year because she's been in Palm Springs due to the wildfires in California.

‚ÄúShe had to go to Palm Springs because her house had been damaged inside, and they had to clean everything,‚Äù Sager explained. ‚ÄúShe was down there for a while, and when she came back, I was kind of stunned by how much weight she'd lost.‚Äù

But was clear was how much Keaton meant to everyone. 

‚ÄúShe was a magic light for everyone,‚Äù Sager added. ‚ÄúI just loved her. She was so special, she just lit up a room with her energy. She was happy and upbeat and taking photographs of everything she saw. She was completely creative; she never stopped creating.‚Äù

In November 2024, Diane Keaton released the song ‚ÄúFirst Christmas,‚Äù which she worked on with Sager and Jonas Myrin.

‚ÄúShe so loved recording this song,‚Äù Sager told PEOPLE. ‚ÄúShe was almost childlike about it.‚Äù

‚ÄúShe was so authentic when she sang it, I mean, she just sang it like she was singing it, and she was sort of acting it, you know, because she is a great actress,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúAnd then she'd start to cry when she was singing it. But she did such a beautiful job.‚Äù

Sager also spoke about Keaton's incredible style, detailing how she took every opportunity to put together an outfit.

 ‚ÄúShe went to the movies always dressed like she was about to shoot another scene for Annie Hall,‚Äù Sager told PEOPLE. ‚ÄúShe'd wear her hats and her jackets and her baggy pants, and her belts. 

‚ÄúShe was a fashion icon of her own making.‚Äù

Another friend of Keaton's spoke with PEOPLE after her death, explaining how the actress spent her final days. 

They detailed how she was ‚Äúfunny right up until the end,‚Äù going on to add that she was ‚Äúone in a million.‚Äù 

‚ÄúShe lived exactly how she wanted to, which was on her own terms, surrounded by the people and things she really loved,‚Äù they added.

We have lost a great actress, clear and still funny, family movies friendly.

Diane was a great actress. Loved her in ‚ÄúLooking For Mr. Goodbar‚Äù. It was sad to hear of her passing and she's truly a hard act to follow. R.I.P. Diane.

Diane was so amazing she always had the biggest and brightest smile, she will be missed‚Ä¶ She was a gift to the world‚Ä¶

Title: Al Pacino's Heartfelt ‚ÄòRegret' Revealed After Diane Keaton's Passing
Description:
Diane Keaton and Al Pacino met while filming the 1972 classic ‚ÄúThe Godfather.‚Äù He played Michael Corleone. She was Kay Adams-Corleone, his on-screen wife. What started as cinematic chemistry soon turned into a real romance that captivated Hollywood. They began dating in 1971 and spent more than a decade in an on-and-off relationship defined by passion, respect, and creative connection. 

But Keaton wanted something lasting. When Pacino never proposed, she made the painful choice to walk away in 1987.

In interviews over the years, Keaton often described Pacino as the great love of her life, while friends now say the feeling was mutual.

Following Keaton's passing on October 11 at age 79, a close friend of Pacino's revealed to the Daily Mail that the actor had been deeply affected by her death.

‚ÄúLooking back, Al admits the love of his life was Diane, who he's always called ‚Äòan amazing woman,'‚Äù the source said. ‚ÄúI know he will forever regret he didn't make his move when he had the chance.‚Äù

The insider added, ‚ÄúFor years after he and Diane split, Al used to say, ‚ÄòIf it's meant to be, it's never too late for a do-over.' But sadly, now it is.‚Äù

Though they both lived in Beverly Hills for years, Pacino and Keaton reportedly hadn't spoken in a long time before her death.

‚ÄúThough he and Diane both lived only a few miles from each other for years, they never spoke,‚Äù the source explained. ‚ÄúI once asked him why, and he told me, ‚ÄòThere's no need to talk with each other. We said everything that needed to be said at the time.‚Äù

Despite the silence between them, those close to Pacino say his affection for Keaton never truly faded.

Now 85, Pacino remains one of Hollywood's most celebrated stars. Though he has dated many women and raised three children, marriage was something he never pursued.

Keaton also followed her own path, embracing independence while raising her two adopted children, Dexter and Duke, with love and quiet strength.

Their story, filled with romance, respect, and reflection, became one of Hollywood's most timeless connections. It was a love that shaped them both, even long after it ended. ‚ÄúShe was his equal in every way,‚Äù a close friend shared. ‚ÄúAnd he knew it.‚Äù

A life lesson‚Ä¶DON'T deny true love.  Embrace it, feed it, let it grow deeper than the roots of the largest tree.

Title: Robert De Niro Shares Touching Tribute to Diane Keaton, His ‚ÄòGodfather Part II' Costar
Description:
Hollywood stars are mourning the loss of Diane Keaton, who passed away on October 11, 2025. Keaton's ‚ÄúThe Godfather Part II‚Äù costar Robert De Niro released a statement following the actress' death.

A post shared by Francis Ford Coppola (@francisfordcoppola)

Following the news of Keaton's passing at age 79, De Niro shared a statement with The Hollywood Reporter.

‚ÄúI am very sad to hear of Diane's passing. I was very fond of her and the news of her leaving us has taken me totally by surprise,‚Äù De Niro's statement read.

‚ÄúI was not expecting her to leave us. She will be missed,‚Äù the actor added. ‚ÄúMay she rest in peace.‚Äù

Keaton starred in ‚ÄúThe Godfather‚Äù trilogy, costarring with De Niro in ‚ÄúThe Godfather Part II‚Äù (1974). The two were also costars in ‚ÄúMarvin's Room‚Äù (1996) and ‚ÄúThe Big Wedding‚Äù (2013).

‚ÄúThe Godfather‚Äù trilogy director, Francis Ford Coppola, posted a touching tribute to Keaton in an October 12 Instagram post.

‚ÄúWords can't express the wonder and talent of Diane Keaton. Endlessly intelligent, so beautiful. From her earliest performances in ‚ÄòHair' and throughout her amazing career, she was an extraordinary actor,‚Äù Coppola wrote.

The director continued, ‚ÄúI saw her in the film ‚ÄòLovers and Other Strangers' and knew I had to have her play Kay in ‚ÄòThe Godfather,' (which she told me she based on my wife Ellie) and her wonderful work in ‚ÄòAnnie Hall' while simultaneously setting a new fashion trend.‚Äù

Coppola added, ‚ÄúEverything about Diane was creativity personified.‚Äù

A post shared by Goldie Hawn (@goldiehawn)

There have been a flood of tributes for Keaton from her many co-stars, including ‚ÄúThe First Wives Club‚Äù stars Bette Midler and Goldie Hawn.

Midler wrote in her tribute, posted on Instagram: ‚ÄúThe brilliant, beautiful, extraordinary Diane Keaton has died. I cannot tell you how unbearably sad this makes me. She was hilarious, a complete original, and completely without guile, or any of the competitiveness one would have expected from such a star.‚Äù

The actress added, ‚ÄúWhat you saw was who she was ‚Ä¶ oh, la, lala!‚Äù

Hawn also shared a heartfelt tribute to Keaton on Instagram. ‚ÄúDiane, we aren't ready to lose you. You've left us with a trail of fairy dust, filled with particles of light and memories beyond imagination,‚Äù she wrote.

The actress continued, ‚ÄúHow do we say goodbye? What words can come to mind when your heart is broken? You never liked praise, so humble, but now you can't tell me to ‚Äòshut up' honey. There was, and will be, no one like you.‚Äù

Hawn noted, ‚ÄúYou stole the hearts of the world and shared your genius with millions, making films that made us laugh and cry in ways only you could. I was blessed to make ‚ÄòFirst Wives Club' with you, our days starting with coffee in the makeup trailer, laughing and joking, right through to the very last day of filming. It was a roller coaster of love.‚Äù

The actress also revealed their hope to live together in the future. ‚ÄúWe agreed to grow old together, and one day, maybe live together with all our girlfriends,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúWell, we never got to live together, but we did grow older together. Who knows ‚Ä¶ maybe in the next life.‚Äù

Hawn added, ‚ÄúShine your fairy dust up there, girlfriend. I'm going to miss the hell out of you. My heart goes out to your beautiful children, Dex and Duke. I love you.‚Äù

Title: Alexis Bellino Reveals What Fans Didn't See from Her Wedding to John Janssen: PHOTOS
Description:
Former ‚ÄúThe Real Housewives of Orange County‚Äù star Alexis Bellino celebrated her wedding day to John Janssen on Oct. 3. The couple's special day was held in Laguna Beach, California, with a few of Bellino's former ‚ÄúReal Housewives‚Äù co-stars in attendance, including Tamra Judge and Jo De La Rosa.

On Oct. 12, Bellino shared even more behind-the-scenes moments of the magical day, including videos of Janssen taking over the microphone and having a rock violinist! 

A post shared by Alexis Bellino (@alexis_bellino)

Alexis Bellino made sure to capture every moment of her wedding to John Janssen. From the beautiful rustic ceremony to the fun-filled reception, the former ‚ÄúReal Housewives‚Äù star shared these intimate moments with her fans on Instagram. 

Bellino's first photos offered a closer look at her romantic wedding ceremony, featuring a sweet moment of her and Janssen holding hands as they gazed into each other's eyes. Another photo captured the stunning setting, Bellino walking down the aisle lined with beautiful flowers and framed by tall trees.

Bellino also shared just how much fun the couple had with their guests during the reception, which included Janssen grabbing the microphone and singing alongside a rock violinist. They're also seen joined by friends on the dancefloor while swaying to Taylor Swift's ‚ÄúLove Story.‚Äù 

According to Bellino's caption for her wedding footage, fans can expect a lot more snapshots and video of her special day. ‚ÄúAs promised, more wedding moments as the photos and videos come in from friends and the best @jeremyjfraser We have SO much more to share!!! Stay tuned over the next few weeks!‚Äù

A post shared by Alexis Bellino (@alexis_bellino)

In an exclusive with People, Bellino opened up about her wedding day, revealing how meaningful it was to include both her and Janssen's children in the celebration. Bellino shares three children with her ex-husband, Jim Bellino, while Janssen is also a father of three from his previous marriage. 

Bellino stated that each of their children played a ‚Äúmeaningful role‚Äù in the wedding, with the reality TV star and her husband giving their children custom bracelets as ‚Äúa symbolic moment of blending  [their] families.‚Äù

On Instagram, Bellino also shared a photo of her and Janssen sharing a kiss with her children happily looking on behind them. ‚ÄúLook at my kids in this moment!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This was the most amazing day. Thank you to @johnwjanssen for loving me exactly how I am. Thank you to our 6 kids for being such good humans,‚Äù she captioned it.

Title: ‚ÄòHaunted Harmony Mysteries' ‚Äî Will Hallmark Continue Franchise After ‚ÄòBuried at C?'
Description:
As Hallmark Channel premieres ‚ÄúHaunted Harmony Mysteries: Buried at C‚Äù on October 12, 2025, sleuthers are likely hoping that the second movie in the franchise isn't the last. 

Good news! It appears two more ‚ÄúHaunted Harmony Mysteries‚Äù starring Tamera Mowry-Housley, Marco Grazzini, and Risteard Cooper are on the way ‚Äî with one movie already filmed and another filming now in Ireland. That means the gap between movies shouldn't be nearly as long as the two years between the first, 2023's ‚ÄúMurder in G Major,‚Äù and the latest installment. 

While promoting ‚ÄúBuried at C‚Äù with Grazzini, Mowry-Housley let it slip during an interview with ‚ÄúGood Day Sacramento‚Äù on October 8 that they were in Ireland filming a fourth movie. 

When she, Grazzini, and Cooper returned to Ireland in early 2025 to film ‚ÄúBuried at C,‚Äù there was plenty of time on their shoot schedule to film a third installment ‚Äî though it's not clear what it will be called or when it will be released. 

According to Ireland's Screen Crew and Services Database, the cast and crew were scheduled to film for more than two months, from February 4 to April 11, in Dublin and in picturesque Wicklow, located about 30 miles south of the city. Given that most Hallmark movies stick to a 15-day production schedule, the cast and crew were able to film two new movies based on Alexia Gordon's Gethsemane Brown Mysteries five-book series. 

In the first ‚ÄúHaunted Harmony Mysteries,‚Äù we meett main character Gethsemane, a former orchestra conductor living in Ireland to teach at a boarding school, St. Brendan's, where she's tasked with turning a motley group of students into an award-winning chorus.

However, when she keeps hearing the same four notes playing in the old Irish house where she's staying, she discovers it's the ghost of one of her music idols, a songwriter-musician, Eamon (played by Cooper), who perished years before in a mysterious murder-suicide.

Able to see his spirit, Gethsemane reluctantly starts working with him to try to solve the mystery and clear his name. She gets assistance from local Inspector O'Reilly, played by Adam Fergus, and her teaching colleague Griff (played by Hallmark fan favorite and ‚ÄúVirgin River‚Äù actor Grazzini.).

A post shared by tameramowryhousley (@tameramowrytwo)

In the synopsis for ‚ÄúBuried at C,‚Äù Hallmark says, ‚ÄúBeloved music teacher Gethsemane Brown returns to solve a new case that hits a little too close to home when her brother, Jackson, is implicated in the murder of local troublemaker Ray.‚Äù 

The logline continues, ‚ÄúGethsemane and spirited partner Eamon join forces with Captain Mac, now a ghost after Ray killed him to cover up the theft of a violin recovered from the Titanic. As the investigation progresses, Gethsemane dives into a tangled web of secrets, stolen artifacts, and family drama to clear her brother's name, all while navigating her own romantic entanglements.‚Äù 

‚ÄúHaunted Harmony Mysteries: Buried at Sea‚Äù premieres on October 12 at 8 p.m. Eastern time, and will be available to stream via Hallmark+ the following day. 

Love Haunted Harmony Mysteries.
So happy that it is not a syrupy, smoochy movie. We all know Hallmark has the same basic
foundation. Girl attracted, then overhears conversation with his old sweetheart, but not the rest
of the story. OR girl on a stepladder, slips into his arms, their eyes meet and you know the rest.
Let's face it, that is not ‚ÄúReal Life‚Äù. If you've seen one, you know how it will go.
Soooo it is refreshing to see something entirely different. Love the interaction of ‚Äúwho done it ‚Äú
And absolutely love the part of the ghost, that she can see. It stays to format of a mystery.
Thank you Hallmark  üôèü¶ã‚ô•Ô∏è

Title: It's Not Apple TV+ Anymore
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Tucked inside a mostly benign press release about the upcoming streaming availability of Joseph Kosinski's recent feature ‚ÄúF1,‚Äù some other news: don't call it Apple TV+ anymore. It's now, per a Monday morning press release, ‚Äúsimply Apple TV, with a vibrant new identity.‚Äù

What that vibrant new identity is actually beyond ‚Äúeasier to remember,‚Äù it's currently unclear. Head on over to the streamer's official website, and everything is still branded ‚ÄúApple TV+.‚Äù For now, the same is still true of the app (at least, on this reporter's iPhone). We can sense an app update in the offing, and fast.

 










Also a question? What this means for Apple's other Apple TV, the company's physical streaming box, which connects to a television to provide access to streaming apps and services. Call it the Apple Box, and be done with it.

Related Stories ‚ÄòDMV' Review: Tim Meadows Brightens Up a CBS Sitcom That Needs to Become a Sturdier Star Vehicle ‚ÄòBridgerton' Season 4 (Finally) Gets a Two-Part Release Date and Teaser, Time to Schedule Your Swooning 

Apple TV+, as it was then known, launched on November 1, 2019 as the tech giant's very first foray into the streaming market. Launch day included the debut of ‚ÄúThe Morning Show,‚Äù as well as the Jason Momoa-led ‚ÄúSee‚Äù and Hailee Steinfeld in ‚ÄúDickinson.‚Äù Later that year, the fledgling streamer also got into the film biz, rolling out films like ‚ÄúHala‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Elephant Queen.‚Äù

 










Along the way, the streamer has enjoyed some serious smash hits on the TV side (like recent winner ‚ÄúThe Studio,‚Äù which recently won 22 Emmys, and enduring fave ‚ÄúSeverance‚Äù). Movies remain top of mind, too, from the massive ‚ÄúF1‚Äù to films from some of Hollywood's biggest names, like Spike Lee and Paul Greengrass, just to name some recent titles. In 2022, ‚ÄúCODA‚Äù won Best Picture at the 94th Academy Awards, which made Apple the first streaming service to win the award.

Coming up next: movies like ‚ÄúThe Family Plan 2,‚Äù ‚ÄúStiller & Meara: Nothing Is Lost,‚Äù ‚ÄúCome See Me in the Good Light,‚Äù and series like ‚ÄúPlurbius.‚Äù Oh, and for ‚ÄúF1‚Äù fans: the Brad Pitt-starring actioner will start streaming on Apple TV (no plus!) on Friday, December 12.

Earlier this year, rival streamer HBO Max similarly trotted out a new (in this case, old) name change, reverting back to its original moniker after trying to make a go out of just ‚ÄúMax‚Äù for nearly two years. Add the HBO, drop the +, whatever it is, it's all a bit cleaner.

Title: ‚ÄòDMV' Review: Tim Meadows Brightens Up a CBS Sitcom That Needs to Become a Sturdier Star Vehicle
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Sadly, we're still a few appearances shy of commencing the Tim Meadowsaissance, heretofore referred to as ‚ÄúThe Meadows' Spring Awakening.‚Äù (Not every name + ‚Äúrenaissance‚Äù rolls off the tongue like ‚ÄúMcConaissance.‚Äù) Yes, the beloved character actor recently reprised his iconic role as Mr. Duvall in the ‚ÄúMean Girls‚Äù musical and jolted extra life into ‚ÄúPeacemaker‚Äù Season 2 as a federal agent with ‚Äúbird blindness,‚Äù but two standout supporting turns in two years (plus recurring voice roles) does not an awakening make. (Blame Paramount for nixing Michel Gondry's musical ‚ÄúGolden,‚Äù which featured Meadows next to Pharrell Williams and Brian Tyree Henry ‚Äî now that could've ushered in an Awakening.)

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòFrankenstein' Review: Jacob Elordi Is the Soul of a Gorgeous Guillermo del Toro Monster Movie Missing Its Maker's Madness ‚ÄòBridgerton' Season 4 (Finally) Gets a Two-Part Release Date and Teaser, Time to Schedule Your Swooning 

‚ÄúDMV‚Äù gets the ‚ÄúSNL‚Äù vet closer to a winter bloom, but through two episodes, the CBS sitcom about beleaguered driving examiners, paper pushers, and desk jockeys isn't providing its star enough fertilizer. (OK, OK, I'll stop with the plant metaphors.) Really, it's under-serving each of its talented cast members, which ‚Äî if we follow our crestfallen leads and look at the bright side ‚Äî at least means it's a solvable problem (unlike the DMV itself).

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






The single-camera comedy starts by admitting what everyone already knows: Nobody likes the DMV. Every driver's worst nightmare ‚Äî yes, even more than crashing their dream car the second it rolls off the lot ‚Äî is being forced to visit the Department of Motor Vehicles, a place where time stops and the red tape rolls on forever. 

Colette (Harriet Dyer) knows the grind all too well. She's been working at the East Hollywood DMV for five years, despite promising herself (and anyone listening) it's just a temp job. Her closest friends aren't clinging to the same sliver of sunshine Colette needs to keep going, but Vic (Tony Cavalero) and Gregg (Meadows) still support her whenever they can. Vic savors life's simple pleasures ‚Äî a meatball sub with crinkled potato chips for lunch, a shirtless afternoon on a hot day ‚Äî even if they come at the expense of others. (That was Gregg's sub, and Vic's co-workers aren't exactly thrilled about their half-nude colleague.)

Gregg is identified in the press notes as a misanthrope, but the jury's still out on that predetermined character trait. Sure, when he mentions his frigid marital bed, it's more statement than complaint, but he's also positioned as Colette's most supportive, encouraging friend. He cares about what counts ‚Äî so far, at least.

 










Much can change after the first hour of a network sitcom, and at least a few things need to in ‚ÄúDMV.‚Äù For starters, Colette feels familiar for the wrong reasons. Both episodes pivot around her crush on Noa (Alex Tarrant), a hunky New Zealander who's only been working at the DMV for a few weeks. Quickly establishing a ‚Äúwill they, won't they‚Äù romance is a safe bet for viewer retention, and their rapport is sound enough. It's just that creator Dana Klein (‚Äú9JKL,‚Äù ‚ÄúFriends with Better Lives‚Äù) seems to be positioning Dyer in a similar dynamic as her breakout role on the Aussie serial rom-com, ‚ÄúColin from Accounts‚Äù ‚Äî awkwardly flirting, awkwardly plotting, and generally embarrassing herself over and over.

Too much of the banter is sloppy and too many of her mistakes are avoidable. (The climax of the pilot really stretches to put Colette in an embarrassing spot.) ‚ÄúDMV‚Äù also recycles too many jokes within the same 20-minute arc. (I'm hesitant to identify them as ‚Äúcallbacks‚Äù ‚Äî a new comedy should be eager to show off new jokes, and the adhesive maxi-pad bit just isn't funny enough for a running gag.) At least we know Dyer is playing in a familiar sandbox, so it's safe to assume she'll start building better castles in time.

Everyone else leaves too little impact. Cavalero worked wonders on ‚ÄúThe Righteous Gemstones,‚Äù and his eccentric ex-bouncer has plenty of untapped potential in the stuffy confines of a government office building. Tarrant is stuck playing a boring dreamboat, making it hard to tell if he'll expand beyond Dyer's dorky straight man. The office manager, Barbara Berry (Molly Kearney), gets points for stretching her well-intentioned buffoon of a boss, while ID photographer Ceci (Gigi Zumbado) barely gets enough screen time to speak her lines.

 










That leaves the two glaring questions facing ‚ÄúDMV's‚Äù first season: Can the visual template lighten up enough to disassociate a fun network sitcom from its infamous real-world setting, and can it seed enough rich material for Meadows (and the rest of the cast) to open up like we know he can? Speaking to the former point, it's great that ‚ÄúDMV‚Äù evokes an actual DMV ‚Äî having been to a few in the greater Los Angeles area, the show's soundstage could sub in for any one of them ‚Äî but the bleak overhead lighting, dark walls, and black office furniture take things a step too far. A comedy stage still needs to be inviting, even if the place it's modeled after isn't.

As for Meadows, he does get the biggest laugh of the first two episodes, so there's hope. Writers need time to get to know their stars' strengths, even if those stars have been brightening our screens for decades. ‚ÄúDMV‚Äù just needs a little fine-tuning, and then we'll be able to tell if it's ready for what it's cast already deserves: a long road ahead.

‚ÄúDMV‚Äù premieres Monday, October 13 at 8:30 p.m. ET on CBS. New episodes will be released weekly and available to stream on Paramount+.

Title: The Onion Is Making Mockumentaries for Real Americans with ‚ÄòJeffrey Epstein: Bad Pedophile'
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Even though the theatrical event of 2025 ‚Äî if not the year's true moment of poetic cinema ‚Äî has come and gone, IndieWire must continue being a website and writing about obvious things like the VistaVision print of ‚ÄúOne Battle After Another.‚Äù But it is worth reflecting on the former, by which we, of course, mean the limited theatrical run of The Onion mockumentary, ‚ÄúJeffrey Epstein: Bad Pedophile.‚Äù 

The 20-minute short is now available for any American idiot to watch YouTube, but the team at the Onion recently screened it, along with the classic Onion limited series ‚ÄúSex House,‚Äù in over 25 independent theaters across the country, from Birmingham, Alabama, to Duluth, Minnesota, and beyond. 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		




Related Stories ‚ÄòFrankenstein' Review: Jacob Elordi Is the Soul of a Gorgeous Guillermo del Toro Monster Movie Missing Its Maker's Madness BAFTA North America's Inaugural Honours Awards for TV, Film, and Video Games Now Won't Roll Out Until Fall 2026 

The success of the one-night-only, self-described ‚ÄúHistoric Cinematic Night of Film at the Movies‚Äù speaks not just to the credibility of America's Finest News Source, but of the increasing ease with which projects and exhibitors can directly collaborate to get around the usual film distribution channels ‚Äî and any risk-aversion that may or may not come with them.  

 










Over the summer, The Onion team observed the staying power of the Epstein files as a news story and decided to commit the whole of their Onion News Network resources to creating a mockumentary around it and trying to make that film as big, ambitious, and wildly funny as the Chicago-based satire team could. The script came together in a matter of days. ‚ÄúI remember walking into the writers' room and seeing [the outline of the film]. On [beat] number eight or nine, it said ‚ÄòHe went to heaven' with a frowny face. That's when I knew it was gonna be truly great,‚Äù Onion CEO Ben Collins told IndieWire. 

They'd even secured release for the short mockumentary through a major distributor. But in the wake of the shooting of Charlie Kirk, the distributor decided to walk away from the project. ‚ÄúTheir PR team [must have] refused to watch the movie because they kept asking if Donald Trump was in it. And we were like, ‚ÄòYeah. But he's on the Knicks.' Like, it's not [real]‚Ä¶ I think it's weird that you would see the name ‚ÄòJeffrey Epstein' and immediately associate it with the president and all of his friends. But it is what it is,‚Äù Collins said. 

Luckily for The Onion team, they didn't have to leave one of their most ambitious video projects at ‚Äúit is what it is.‚Äù CMO Leila Brillson was determined to pursue independent theatrical screenings, partnering with indie theaters across the country. ‚ÄúWhat's exciting about this process is that it was a bummer to find ourselves holding the bag on something, but we also created our own pipeline, which was really exciting. We created our own relationships with these theaters that we were able to pump this out without relying on anyone except the technology that exists to send this to each other,‚Äù Brillson told IndieWire.     

 










It was as simple as emailing jeffreyepstein@theonion.com for independent theaters to request the DCP (Digital Cinema Package, the kind of file used to play movies on digital projectors) on Friday, October 2. Both Onion CEO Ben Collins and CMO Leila Brillson told IndieWire they were blown away by the response and by what building their own distribution pipeline could unlock for The Onion in the future. 

‚ÄúThere is a feeling that there's not a lot to rally around right now. Providing that kind of catharsis is so important to our readers and our audience. And once we took a look at this thing and laughed our faces off, we knew we had the opportunity to bring people together and have a rallying cry, flashpoint moment that we can point to this single, particular date and give people something they can all go to as a group,‚Äù Brillson said. 

Once The Onion team put out the call, they found out they had friends (with access to independent theaters) everywhere. ‚ÄúWithin 24 hours, we had dozens of requests all throughout the world to show this thing locally,‚Äù Collins said. ‚ÄúWe're letting [the indie theaters] keep the gate. We're letting them donate it to charity, do whatever they want to do with it. We're doing it exclusively so people see the film and to support a difficult ride indie theaters [have had] in the last few years as well.‚Äù 

 










‚ÄúThree cities in Missouri are screening this film, and I just think that's really exciting and really speaks to the pockets of interest that you kind of forget about when you're subsumed into this mass mediated space,‚Äù Brillson added. ‚ÄúBut there are people who are ready to watch something like this that is a little out of left field.‚Äù 

The motto of The Onion is ‚ÄúTu stultus es‚Äù (roughly, ‚ÄúYou are stupid‚Äù), but both Brillson and Collins told IndieWire that screening something like ‚ÄúJeffrey Epstein: Bad Pedophile‚Äù proves you don't have to over-engineer ‚Äúcontent‚Äù to be value-neutral slop in order to garner an audience, whatever the demographic breakdown. 

‚ÄúI actually say this all the time to Ben ‚Äî because there is that anti-woke crowd that is so loud, we feel like there's this massive shift and we are watching theater chains and people making the economic decisions ‚Äî marketers, media buyers, whoever ‚Äî make this huge shift to the right. And you know, it doesn't make a tremendous amount of economic sense,‚Äù Brillson said. ‚ÄúActually having some values works. And the nice thing is, all of the people going to this are supporting indie theaters. They're giving their money directly to these people who get to keep it.‚Äù 

 










‚ÄúThe comedy that you see that's very paid for, that's very expensive? The, you know, Riyadh Comedy Festival thing that's going on? Those people have pretended to be censored and had a really hard time, like their speech is being taken away, but they're being paid millions of dollars by the richest people in the world to protect the status quo. And most people want something like [‚ÄòJeffrey Epstein: Bad Pedophile'],‚Äù Collins added. ‚ÄúActual people will drive out of their way, will beg their theaters to air something this stupid. That's where the actual populace is. That's where real America is. It's not with this other, very contrived, anti-woke thing that's been going on for the last few years.‚Äù 

As it so often is, The Onion is right ‚Äî We are stupid, and the key to making good things is in figuring out how to come together with other (stupid) people. ‚ÄúWe feel like we had a cheat code, I think, with rebuilding the newspaper last year. We had to do the same thing. We didn't even know there were middlemen that would go and make you a newspaper and cut off, you know, half your profits. We just went to the place out by O'Hare Airport that makes newspapers and asked, ‚ÄòWould you guys print something for us?,'‚Äù Collins said. ‚ÄúThe whole thing feels kind of charmed.‚Äù

 










‚ÄúJeffrey Epstein: Bad Pedophile‚Äù is now available to stream on YouTube.

Title: ‚ÄòBridgerton' Season 4 (Finally) Gets a Two-Part Release Date and Teaser, Time to Schedule Your Swooning
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Finally, something to look forward to in the bitter days of late winter. Netflix announced early Monday morning that its smash hit series ‚ÄúBridgerton,‚Äù based on the beloved romance novels from Julia Quinn, will return in early 2026. Well, with a caveat: like Season 3, Season 4 will arrive in two parts.

The streamer has announced that Part 1 of the season, including the first four episodes, will drop on January 29, 2026, with Part 2 (also four episodes) following on February 26, 2026. Netflix previously employed a similar release strategy with Season 3 in 2024, splitting that season over two releases during early summer. Talk about delaying the gratification!

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòDMV' Review: Tim Meadows Brightens Up a CBS Sitcom That Needs to Become a Sturdier Star Vehicle ‚ÄòA House of Dynamite' Star Idris Elba on Picking Up Morgan Freeman's Mantle as the Go-to Head of State 

During a February event held in London, current showrunner Jess Brownell teased that the forthcoming season is the ‚ÄúBridgerton‚Äù season most ‚Äúfaithful‚Äù to the respective novel, and one that will kick off with a masquerade ball. (Still, we previously wondered just how faithful this season will be, considering some sticky elements of the novel.)

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






Per this season's official logline: ‚ÄúThe fourth season of ‚ÄòBridgerton' turns its focus to bohemian second son Benedict (Luke Thompson). Despite his elder and younger brothers both being happily married, Benedict is loath to settle down ‚Äî until he meets a captivating Lady in Silver at his mother's masquerade ball.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe theme of the season is really about true love being somewhere in between fantasy and reality,‚Äù Brownell also noted.

In May, the streamer announced that the fifth and sixth seasons of the smash hit had been greenlit, though it's unclear which siblings they will focus on and when they will arrive.

This season stars Luke Thompson (Benedict Bridgerton), Yerin Ha (Sophie Baek), Jonathan Bailey (Anthony Bridgerton), Victor Alli (Lord John Stirling), Adjoa Andoh (Lady Danbury), Julie Andrews (Lady Whistledown), Lorraine Ashbourne (Mrs. Varley), Masali Baduza (Michaela Stirling), Nicola Coughlan (Penelope Bridgerton), Hannah Dodd (Francesca Stirling), Daniel Francis (Lord Marcus Anderson), Ruth Gemmell (Violet Bridgerton), Florence Hunt (Hyacinth Bridgerton), Martins Imhangbe (Will Mondrich), Claudia Jessie (Eloise Bridgerton), Luke Newton (Colin Bridgerton), Golda Rosheuvel (Queen Charlotte), Will Tilston (Gregory Bridgerton), Polly Walker (Portia Featherington), Emma Naomi (Alice Mondrich), Hugh Sachs (Brimsley), plus Simone Ashley (Kate Bridgerton), Isabella Wei (Posy Li), Michelle Mao (Rosamund Li), and Katie Leung (Lady Araminta Gun).

 










Check out the first official teaser for the fourth season of ‚ÄúBridgerton‚Äù below, plus two new photos.

Title: Can M. Night Shyamalan's ‚ÄòMagic 8 Ball' Series Surprise the Way Mattel's ‚ÄòBarbie' Did? ‚ÄòReply Hazy'
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Even a Magic 8 Ball couldn't have seen this one coming. ‚ÄúThe Sixth Sense‚Äù director M. Night Shyamalan is set to direct a series for Mattel Studios based on its Magic 8 Ball toy. 

In an Instagram post announcing the project ‚Äî certainly a twist from one of the masters of them if there ever was one ‚Äî Shyamalan said he's been ‚Äúworking on this for a couple years.‚Äù 

Brad Falchuk, known as a writer on ‚ÄúGlee,‚Äù ‚ÄúAmerican Horror Story,‚Äù and ‚ÄúPose,‚Äù is serving as the writer, co-creator, and co-showrunner of the series, and it's currently in development. The live-action series is being described by Mattel as meant to place Magic 8 Ball ‚Äúas the centerpiece of a high-concept, character-driven supernatural drama that blends psychological intensity with cultural intrigue.‚Äù 

 








Related Stories It's Not Apple TV+ Anymore ‚ÄòDMV' Review: Tim Meadows Brightens Up a CBS Sitcom That Needs to Become a Sturdier Star Vehicle 

That actually signals to us that this is not strictly a kids series based on a toy. In fact, there were a lot of skeptics when ‚ÄúBarbie‚Äù was first put into development by Mattel. So would ‚ÄúMagic 8 Ball‚Äù have an equal chance of surprising audiences, blending some shameless commercialism with a highly talented auteur director? 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






If we asked the Magic 8 Ball, we think it might say ‚ÄúReply hazy, try again.‚Äù 

Since ‚ÄúBarbie‚Äù opened in 2023, Mattel and chief Robbie Brenner have been kicking around a number of different films and series, many of which have yet to materialize. In post-production now are ‚ÄúMasters of the Universe‚Äù from Laika filmmaker Travis Knight, which is a live-action film that brings the He-Man and Skeletor characters to life and is set at Amazon MGM, and also ‚ÄúMatchbox,‚Äù which is an action film set at Apple based on the toy cars that stars John Cena. 

But there's a number of others that are in early stages that have us asking the Magic 8 Ball for some guidance. There's an ‚ÄúAmerican Girl‚Äù series that sounds an awful lot like a recent ‚ÄúSNL‚Äù sketch, a live-action ‚ÄúBarney‚Äù movie that originally had Daniel Kaluuya attached but is now being written by Ayo Edebiri, Jon M. Chu and J.J. Abrams' ‚ÄúHot Wheels‚Äù movie, ‚ÄúRock ‚ÄòEm Sock ‚ÄòEm Robots‚Äù with Vin Diesel, ‚ÄúPolly Pocket‚Äù starring Lily Collins and produced by Reese Witherspoon after Lena Dunham exited, and at one point a ‚ÄúThomas & Friends‚Äù movie that was meant to be directed by Marc Forster, to name just a few.

It's hard to not point to Martin Scorsese directing the ‚ÄúKool-Aid‚Äù movie on ‚ÄúThe Studio‚Äù and just write this off, but Mattel with ‚ÄúBarbie‚Äù quickly proved to be the test case other companies are looking to when it comes to pairing brands with entertainment in more subtle ways. 

 










For Shyamalan, this marks his return to TV after directing and EP'ing ‚ÄúServant‚Äù for Apple, and his last film was ‚ÄúTrap,‚Äù which grossed $84 million worldwide. Not counting something like ‚ÄúGlass‚Äù that is a sequel to ‚ÄúUnbreakable,‚Äù you'd have to go all the way back to ‚ÄúThe Last Airbender‚Äù in 2010 to find an example where Shyamalan was a director-for-hire working on some existing IP. That movie made $320 million but would be safe to say it was not among his better films.

Title: OsamaSon: psykotic Album Review
Description:
7.2

Genre:

Rap

Label:

Atlantic / Motion Music

Reviewed:

October 13, 2025

I was in for a rude awakening when I went to a Che show in Brooklyn a couple weeks ago. I observed from the venue's balcony as the Atlanta rapper strutted onstage, pleading for mosh pits and making devil horns with his fingers. ‚ÄúOpen that shit up!‚Äù Che snarled, over and over again. He was so hellbent on manufacturing the destruction his music encouraged that it soon became obvious he was barely even rapping his songs. After a while it felt awkward, almost like the crowd was meant to perform for him. And listen, I get it: The bloodcurdling shrieks and 808 avalanches are meant to inspire group catharsis. Everybody who makes ‚Äúrage‚Äù rap performs with this in mind. But all I could think was, Damn, when is my generation gonna move on from biting Carti?

If there's anyone who can propel rage in a new direction, it's OsamaSon. The South Carolina rapper has already inspired copycats of his own. But engaging with the scene necessarily means brushing past whichever version of Playboi Carti its leaders are currently modeling themselves after‚ÄîOsama included. No matter how effective the execution, this process is getting monotonous. There's a beauty and a curiosity in dissecting references that feel distant. That feeling is extremely rare in rage rap‚Äîeverything sprouts from low-hanging fruit: Rolling Loud clips, Hot Topic merch, Opium archive pages. So when Osama dropped Jump Out in January, the way he was evolving got me out of my seat: He sustained his melodies with a puerile, sing-songy twang; his cyborgian cadence departed from Carti's alien lilt; his beats were at times sludgier and more neurotic. On his new record, psykotic, OsamaSon doesn't lean any further into the orbit of his lodestar, but he isn't leaving it either.

It's a frustrating dynamic for a release that arrives at the apex of his career so far. Instead of affirming OsamaSon as a unique entity in his own lane, psykotic refurbishes his comfort zone. ‚ÄúWhats Happening‚Äù is immediately one of the hardest tracks in O's catalog, its choppy synth lurch reminiscent of Osama Season's 8-bit churn. At its core are hypercompressed murmurs from Gucci Mane's ‚ÄúShirt Off,‚Äù punctuated by Osama's screwfaced chirrups. Central to the track, though, is a hook familiar enough to send shockwaves: ‚ÄúI take my shirt off and all the hoes stop breathin'.‚Äù For a moment as cool as this to also be potentially inspired by Whole Lotta Red is deflating. I almost wanna wipe that album from my memory just so I can experience this with rose-tinted glasses.

I first heard psykotic on CD‚Äîthe label was so scared of leaks they refused to send a digital stream‚Äìand the earbuds and Walkman I received with it were barely built for the muggy distortion baked into the production. Ten seconds into the intro's wormhole of clipping tumult, I honestly thought producer Warren Hunter broke the Walkman. The lowend claps crammed into its rhythmic nexus are the only sounds that made it out alive. Hunter also helms ‚ÄúFMJ‚Äù and ‚ÄúGet away,‚Äù tracks whose clumps of 808 fuzz land like brass knuckles to the spleen. If production like this wasn't all over Ken Carson's More Chaos, it'd hit even harder, but then again, he and Osama have been swapping similar beats from the same producers since 2023. All the more reason to pivot in a new direction. Not all beats here are weapons of mass destruction, though: producer ok's breezy Pi'erre Bourne replica, ‚ÄúShe woke Up,‚Äù is disappointing; Rok and Gyro's synth-encrusted utopia, ‚Äúyea i kno‚Äù is staggering.

Vocal dynamism is what gives psykotic its style. OsamaSon's accounts of moving bricks and letting bullets fly have never seemed believable, but the way he contorts his pitch and manipulates the cracks in his voice turns his role-playing into must-see TV. He's been honing that pitched-down croak on ‚ÄúMaag Dump‚Äù since last year's face-scrunching ‚Äújust score it.‚Äù When his voice is pitched up, like on ‚ÄúFunction‚Äù or ‚ÄúGintama,‚Äù he sounds so geeked up he might pop. Osama is at his most earnest when he yearns for private affection on ‚ÄúIn It‚Äù and ‚ÄúGet away,‚Äù the latter spotlighting him at his most despondent. Rap-singing a hook that's more Chino Moreno than Jordan Carter, he's never sounded this honest: ‚ÄúI know it's all yours/You never called for it/Sometimes I feel like that you didn't wanna walk for it/Didn't wanna crawl for it/I put in my all for it.‚Äù

As a record, psykotic mostly accomplishes what it sets out to do, and yet it's hard to shake my cynicism. At its peak‚Äîthinking of ‚ÄúHabits,‚Äù ‚ÄúAddicted,‚Äù and that run from ‚ÄúIn It‚Äù to ‚ÄúWhats Happening‚Äù‚Äîit's fevered and galvanic, like how it feels to be so fried you can't tell if you're scared shitless or having the time of your life. But OsamaSon and his collaborators seem determined to route that turbulent energy‚Ä¶ right back to his starting point. On ‚ÄúFMJ,‚Äù Osama's stone-cold, dreary-eyed drone holds firm in the face of 808 torrents and synth trills. What follows is a surprise verse from Che, who's been rapping like he just rediscovered ‚ÄúJumpOutTheHouse‚Äù and can't get it out of his head. His Auto-Tuned yelps, meant to feel exhilarating, instead feel laborious, especially when you know he's talented enough to cultivate something original. In a sudden shift mid-verse, Che swaps his WLR impression for a stoic, guttural warble that lasts no more than three seconds. ‚ÄúI was with Lil O/We got O's/Smokin' buku bitches,‚Äù he intones, briefly treading a new path before retreating back to safety. On paper, the line means nothing, but its delivery suggests salvation from d√©j√† vu. Or maybe that's wishful thinking.

The new artists of our time should be taking pride in subverting the formulas of their predecessors. Kill your fucking idols! Remember when Young Thug wanted to one-up his GOAT Lil Wayne so bad that he tried to drop Tha Carter VI before him? What resulted from that turned out to be more subversive and more iconic than anything Weezy has dropped since. Someone let the kids know they're just as capable of pulling that off.

Title: King Krule Joins Tara Lily on New Song ‚ÄúTropical Storm‚Äù: Listen
Description:
Tara Lily, the British-Bengali musician who's based in South London, has shared a new song featuring King Krule dubbed ‚ÄúTropical Storm.‚Äù She describes the mellow collaboration with Archy Marshall as being ‚Äúa lucid dream playing in our minds again and again.‚Äù Give the song a listen below.

‚ÄúTropical Storm‚Äù is the lead single from Lily's upcoming record Quiet Nights (Early Takes). That four-song EP is out November 7 via Tru Thoughts. Discussing the upcoming record, Lily said, ‚ÄúQuiet Nights are some of the early sketches from a deadly quiet and beautiful period of time. For myself it was a time of stripping back, dropping down into the ground and channelling something raw and real.‚Äù Her debut album, Speak in the Dark, came out last year.

King Krule's most recent album Space Heavy, in which he sung about love and his newfound status as a father, came out in 2023. He followed up that fourth studio LP with the concert film You'll Never Guess What Happened Next that same year, and then the four-song Shhhhhhh! EP in 2024.

Read about King Krule's album The OOZ at No. 60 in ‚ÄúThe 200 Best Albums of the 2010s‚Äù and revisit Jazz Monroe's interview ‚ÄúKing Krule: The Wizard of Ooz.‚Äù

Title: Snooper: Worldwide Album Review
Description:
7.5

Genre:

Rock

Label:

Third Man

Reviewed:

October 13, 2025

Considering the essential role that drum machines play in egg punk, it's a bit of a shock that Snooper‚Äîarguably the genre's biggest band right now‚Äînever used one until the end of last year. While swinging from one tour route to another, all while punching in at their day jobs, the Nashville five-piece suddenly found the beating heart of egg punk sitting in their lap. Singer Blair Tramel and guitarist Connor Cummins started writing songs synced to the hardline rhythms of a vintage Zoom MRT-3, drawn to the propulsive nature of an intentionally repetitive structure. Worldwide, the culmination of those brainstorm sessions, is expectedly jacked up and alert. It's the beefy older brother to 2023's slinky art-kid debut Super Sn√µ√µper, but Snooper's unwieldy creativity bends its rigidity into moments of zany malleability.

As if powered by a metronome plugged into a high-voltage outlet, Snooper hit the ground running on Worldwide and never stop across its 28-minute runtime, turning into varsity sprinters with a cross-country runner's endurance. From the descending, jittery melody in opener ‚ÄúOpt Out‚Äù to the gloomy '80s bass casting a British new-wave shadow over ‚ÄúWorldwide,‚Äù each member of Snooper‚ÄîTramel, Cummins, guitarist Conner Sullivan, bassist Happy Haugen, and drummer Brad Barteau‚Äîvaults through a series of musical high-knees and shuttle lines. If their aerobic endorphins weren't already infectious, Snooper kick it up a notch with electronics on ‚ÄúStar 69‚Äù and ‚ÄúPom Pom.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey made me the team captain/And told me, ‚ÄòMake it happen,'‚Äù Tramel chants during the latter. Her teammates fortify the pep rally: pulling guitar strings across the fretboard, splicing drum beats into lightening-fried stutters, layering dog barks like cymbal hits.

Snooper thrive when locking eyes with the listener and tapping their wristwatch. On ‚ÄúCompany Call‚Äù and ‚ÄúOn Line,‚Äù they add gloss to both re-recorded versions from last year's split 7" with Prison Affair, letting Haugen and Barteau steer with a thundering bassline and the accoutrements of a full drum kit determined to render the drum machine obsolete. There's no Pro Tools trickery speeding up the tempo without altering the pitch; Snooper really are playing that fast, and they've got the bloody fingers to prove it. The album's best sprint is an unlikely cover of the Beatles' ‚ÄúCome Together.‚Äù Snooper smash their pointer finger on the fast forward button of a CD player, zipping through the Abbey Road single in highlight reel-style. The all-timer bassline waggles in Haugen's hands like that old rubber pencil trick, the guitars wait on the sidelines for the riff-ready chorus, and sparse drums more than halve the original's runtime. It'd be a perplexing cover if not for how well the imagery aligns with the papier-m√¢ch√© puppets of Snooper's concerts: juju eyeballs, holy roller getup, hair down to his knee (singular).

Despite its musical brevity, Worldwide is the wordiest batch of songs Tramel has ever written. After years of hearing fans scream lyrics back at her, the vocalist fine tuned her phrasing to champion the importance of cheering yourself on, learning how to use your voice, and seizing the benefits of pressure before it squishes you flat. ‚ÄúWhere did all these words come from? Were they borrowed from someone?‚Äù Tramel wonders in ‚ÄúGuard Dog,‚Äù as if stunned by her own poetic license. By letting herself go long, though, Tramel finds a new way to inject Snooper's songs with unpredictable pathways while the rhythms otherwise stay locked in a groove.

But what happens to all that reclaimed time? Snooper wind it around their shoulders like arcade tickets, march up to the prize counter, and cash it in for an album-ending psych-rock blowout. ‚ÄúRelay‚Äù switches from a gritty rock song to a sassy riff immersed in fuzz. It moves cleanly into the four-minute closer ‚ÄúSubdivison‚Äù‚Äîsprawling for egg punk‚Äîthat embarks on a heady, rhythm section-focused exodus akin to the driving garage rock of Osees. During the song's claustrophobic extended jam, Snooper find a new side of themselves willing to breathe mid-song to build tension. Recorded with John Congleton, marking the band's first time working with a studio producer, Worldwide fortifies Snooper's sound by forcing the stiff loops of a drum machine to warp under the weight of their ricocheting guitars. Studio time didn't kill the punk band. It granted them space to play faster and looser without losing any of the fun.

Title: Klein: sleep with a cane Album Review
Description:
7.7

Genre:

Experimental

Label:

Parkwuud Entertainment

Reviewed:

October 13, 2025

Klein used to work as a ‚Äúlogger‚Äù on a reality TV show, where she would record what cast members were doing in excruciating detail for use in B-roll shots. It's a detail I can't get out of my head, because not only is it hilarious, but there's also something obsessive and mundane about it: Here's one guy going to sleep, here's another person starting an argument. In an interview with Pitchfork, Klein noted how easily TV can be manipulated by people willing to distort the narrative, as when her fellow loggers would exclude activities by certain actors to make them look bad.

Klein is the complete opposite. She puts everything out as it comes, raw and unfiltered. It's obsessive and mundane in a different way, suffused with meaning even at its most impenetrable. After two albums of searing guitar noise, sleep with a cane feels like a retreat into the shroud of her earlier work. She finds solace, and intrigue, in the billowing folds of ambient music, but also in the sounds around her: her family, her house, the street. She's her own logger, cataloguing moods and feelings with a comprehensiveness that would be exhausting if it weren't so compelling.

In a quote to HotNewHipHop (she is signed to Roc Nation, after all), Klein calls sleep with a cane a ‚Äúcoming of age‚Äù release, and also a mixtape. It's a mixtape in the sense that it's not meant as a cohesive album, rather a grab bag of assorted goodies that amounts to ‚Äúan epic ambient tape,‚Äù also her words. The irony is that in its patient, almost tender 91-minute sprawl, sleep with a cane is actually one of her more well-rounded and definitive releases. There is an epic scope to tracks like ‚Äúit is what it is in d minor,‚Äù a 13-minute drone track based around a distant piano that sounds like an exploded version of her modern classical suite Harmattan.

Klein's musical world has always been porous, as she flits from modern classical to post-club to drone and whatever you call her On the Radar freestyle, where she Auto-Tune raps about ‚Äúmini-mes‚Äù and staying at the bottom, before a guitar break marries the stabby freeform spray of late-'60s Neil Young solos with the buzzsaw tones of early '90s Darkthrone. The longer tracks on sleep with a cane, like the despondent and searching ‚ÄúFamily Employment 2008-2014‚Äù or the 10-minute Ecco2k collaboration that reminds me of a ketted-out version of the ‚ÄúJustin Bieber 800% Slower‚Äù video, are broken up by bits of distortion or periodic crawls into hidey-holes. ‚Äúbruk promise‚Äù sounds like a microphone caught in a dust storm, and some fetchingly weird guitar playing is broken up by what could be fireworks or gunshots on the desolate ‚Äúfor 6 guitar, damilola.‚Äù It's a tribute to a murdered London schoolboy that feels both devastating and obtuse, in classic Klein fashion. A promised collab with Manchester ambient stars Space Afrika manifests as a 16-second snippet with some unintelligible dialogue, while ‚Äúscore for J‚Äù has some Springsteenian harmonica, mournful and anthemic, undergirding a track that barely holds itself together. It's a lot at once, but it makes a weird sort of sense in Klein's world, blurring humor, absurdity, and grief in a way that feels like the exact opposite of irony.

Listening to sometimes impenetrable records like sleep with a cane, it's important to remember two things about Klein: One, she's funny as hell. Second, her music always means something. It's never weird for the sake of being weird. ‚ÄúInforma,‚Äù one of the album's most unnerving tracks, originally appeared as part of an entertaining online lecture that Klein gave for Frankfurt's St√§delschule; the track wrestles with a line from a news broadcast about young artists who are ‚Äúleaving violence behind‚Äù for ‚Äúcreativity and independence,‚Äù with a belligerent repetition that borders on the Bluntian. Klein chose the quote as a means to address how people often see her as some sort of diamond in the rough, an exceptional case, as a young Black woman from South London making a style of music more associated with academic institutions than anything closer to what she grew up on.

But it doesn't feel like she's making music for anyone but herself, and it's an immense privilege to hear it. With her fiery guitar largely relegated to the background, sleep with a cane is a softer release, but it's hardly relaxing. It closes with ‚Äúrich dad poor dad,‚Äù the closest thing here to hip-hop, mainly because it has intelligible lyrics. The instrumental sounds like a cloud-rap production blown to smithereens and slowed to a crawl, with Klein's vocal wobbling over top: ‚ÄúMy mum comes down and says, ‚ÄòBirds are watching'/I look around our home is burning/Another gone/Another dying,‚Äù she says, voice breaking on the word ‚Äúcrossroads,‚Äù repeated like a hymn.

Is the crossroads of ‚Äúrich dad poor dad‚Äù meant to evoke the crossroads of Robert Johnson, another artist who bared his soul on records that seemed made for his own personal universe, logging his own actions and obsessions for the rest of the world to see? I'm not sure it matters. It's hard to compare Klein to anyone else at this point. She's the lead in her own imaginary reality show, where a genius making strange, unstructured music becomes a superstar beloved by people from all backgrounds. Listening to sleep with a cane, that scenario doesn't seem so made-up.

Title: The Right's Secret Plan to Help Billionaires Buy Elections
Description:
The following is adapted from Master Plan: The Hidden Plot to Legalize Corruption in America, the new book from David Sirota's investigative newsroom, The Lever. Click here for a discount and a free e-book version.


	On the 20th anniversary of the creation of the Roberts Supreme Court, one point of consensus persists: Most Americans believe money corrupts the political process ‚Äî and they want to overturn the Citizens United precedent that empowers oligarchs to buy elections. 


	And yet, in two little-noticed cases ‚Äî including one spearheaded by Vice President J.D. Vance ‚Äî the high court could soon do the opposite, eliminating the last restrictions on campaign donations and obstructing law enforcement's efforts to halt bribery. 




			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	As we recount in our new book Master Plan, the Citizens United case was the culmination of conservatives' 50-year master plan to deregulate the campaign finance system and legalize corruption. What started as an incendiary memo from soon-to-be Supreme Court Justice Lewis Powell became one ruling equating money with constitutionally protected speech and another extending personhood rights to corporations. 

	











	Soon after John Roberts and Sam Alito were installed on the court two decades ago, they helped deliver the apotheosis: 2010's Citizens United opinion manufacturing the legal fiction that spending by ‚Äî and donations to ‚Äî allegedly independent political groups cannot be limited because those expenditures ‚Äúdo not give rise to corruption or the appearance of corruption.‚Äù

	











	Though Citizens United unleashed a 28-fold increase in election spending, the ruling preserved the legality of campaign contribution limits. But they could now be destroyed by Vance's case aiming to reverse a 2001 Supreme Court ruling and eliminate restrictions on political parties' coordinated spending with candidates. If those rules are killed off, party committees could become pass-through conduits for big donors to circumvent donation limits and deliver much larger payments in support of lawmakers who can reward them with government favors.





	
		Editor's picks
	
	











	
	
		
					The 250 Greatest Albums of the 21st Century So Far		
	














	
	
		
					The 100 Best TV Episodes of All Time		
	









	Once again, the master planners are conjuring a legal fiction ‚Äî House Republicans' amicus brief insists that because parties pool money from many contributors, that ‚Äúsignificantly dilutes the potential for any particular donor to exercise a corrupting influence over any particular candidate‚Äù who ultimately benefits from their cash. In essence, they're asking justices to believe a bank CEO's donation to a political party coordinating with a lawmaker's campaign can in no way influence how that lawmaker drafts banking legislation. 


	A robust argument for preserving the existing restrictions is certainly possible ‚Äî but the defense side of the case has already been thrown into chaos. After Donald Trump was sworn in, his solicitor general ended the Justice Department's support of the current law and joined with the plaintiffs attacking it. The Supreme Court then assigned the defense to a conservative lawyer who served as Chief Justice Roberts' clerk when he engineered the original Citizens United ruling. This same conservative attorney charged with defending the last remaining campaign finance statutes recently pressed justices to limit the scope of federal anti-bribery laws, which are now also in the legal crosshairs.


	In a concurrent case unfolding amid Washington's bacchanal of self-enrichment scandals, Cincinnati's former Democratic city councilman P.G. Sittenfeld is asking the Supreme Court to overturn his bribery conviction after an FBI sting caught him accepting a $20,000 campaign contribution in exchange for supporting a local development project.





	
		Related Content
	
	






	
	
		
					Trump Is Letting Qatar Build a Military Facility in the U.S. and MAGA Is Not Happy		
	









	
	
		
					J.D. Vance Tried to Evade Journalists' Questions. It Did Not Go Well		
	









	
	
		
					The Supreme Court Is Ruling on Conversion Therapy. What Could Go Wrong!		
	









	
	
		
					Supreme Court Ethics Issues Trace to John Roberts' ‚ÄòOriginal Sin,' New Book Alleges		
	









	Notably, Sittenfeld has already been pardoned by Trump, making him by his own admission the first person in history to appeal a case he's already been absolved from.  He is receiving pro bono legal counsel from the most Trump-connected law firm in America, he is being personally represented by Trump's former solicitor general, and his appeal is being supported by an army of former elected officials. 

	











	Those circumstances and all that legal firepower make clear that this is less about one shady municipal deal and more about broadening a string of rulings making it increasingly impossible to prosecute public corruption cases. 


	That decade-long line of jurisprudence has seen the Supreme Court overturn bribery convictions of former Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell, aides to then-New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, and associates of former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, narrowing the definition of what an ‚Äúofficial act‚Äù in a quid pro quo situation is. Building off that, the court then declared that a public official reaping a payment from the recipient of government contracts is not engaging in illegal bribery, but is merely accepting a legal ‚Äúgratuity.‚Äù 


	Taken together, the story is as sordid as it seems: As some justices were secretly accepting gifts from billionaires, they were using these cases to rule that the real problem in American politics is not egregious corruption, but instead overly stringent anti-corruption laws. 


	‚ÄúOur concern is not with tawdry tales of Ferraris, Rolexes, and ball gowns,‚Äù wrote Chief Justice Roberts when he tossed McDonnell's conviction. ‚ÄúIt is instead with the broader legal implications of the government's boundless interpretation of the federal bribery statute.‚Äù


	‚ÄúYou can buy influence all you want,‚Äù former Trump-appointed U.S. Attorney David Devillers told us when asked to summarize the effect of these rulings. ‚ÄúYou can buy someone a yacht but if there's no quid pro quo tied to it, there's no official act tied to it, then it's not a federal crime.‚Äù 


	This might explain why law enforcement officials declined to charge Trump's prospective border czar Tom Homan when the FBI reportedly caught him accepting a bag full of $50,000 in cash from those seeking government contracts from a future Trump administration. With America's anti-corruption laws weakened, a Justice Department official didn't deny the veracity of the reporting, he instead insisted the events represented ‚Äúno credible evidence of any criminal wrongdoing‚Äù ‚Äî a talking point now being echoed by Vance. 


	As Trump now dismantles the Justice Department unit that prosecutes public corruption, Sittenfeld's appeal aims to take the Supreme Court's legal assault on anti-bribery laws even farther. In legal briefs, his lawyers are offering a novel theory: they insinuate that pay-to-play culture is now so pervasive that it should no longer be considered prosecutable.

	











	Citing Trump reportedly asking oil executives for $1 billion of campaign cash in exchange for government favors, Sittenfeld's Supreme Court petition laments that ‚Äúprosecutor could doubtless present this meeting alone as at least ambiguous evidence of a quid pro quo.‚Äù The petition then asserts that if Sittenfeld's conviction is allowed to stand, ‚Äúpoliticians are open to prosecution if they say anything during these often informal, unscripted conversations that can be read to even hint at a possible quid pro quo.‚Äù


	In past eras, the Supreme Court might be expected to evaluate the merits of the Vance and Sittenfeld cases, and issue narrow rulings honoring past precedents. But in the Roberts Court era, judicial respect for so-called stare decisis has often been jettisoned on campaign finance matters.


	Consider the tactics of the backers of Citizens United: They manufactured a fight with federal officials over the classification of a little-noticed documentary film not so much because they cared about the movie, but because they saw a chance to elicit a corruption-legalizing scheme they knew Congress would never legislate. Indeed, the case was meticulously engineered to give the newly conservative court the opportunity not merely to arbitrate the minor dispute, but to instead ignore stare decisis and ‚Äúgo big,‚Äù as one of the case's architects told us.


	It's the same dynamic today: Conservative groups behind today's two new cases undoubtedly hope that their spats over the esoterica of campaign finance and bribery law prompt the even-more-conservative court to not merely mediate these specific conflicts, but to instead issue broad rulings incinerating any remaining deterrents to pay-to-play corruption.


	And yet if plaintiffs get their way in these cases, all is not lost. 


	Yes, in buying elections, packing the courts, and eliciting precedents legalizing corruption, the master planners have created the democracy crisis, pushing America one step closer to the kleptocratic death spiral of history's collapsing empires. 


	But no, that freefall is not yet inevitable ‚Äî before we hurtle over the precipice, there are still a few off ramps.


	One of them is a constitutional amendment to overturn Citizens United that would stop equating money with First Amendment-protected speech and allow our communities to restrict the flow of cash into politics. This may seem unrealistic because of the high threshold for ratification, but a growing number of states have already expressed support for such a measure, which was just reintroduced in Congress.

	











	Shorter term, another off ramp runs through Montana. Thirteen years after the Supreme Court gutted the state's century-old anti-corruption law, Montana luminaries of both parties are now spearheading a ballot initiative circumventing Citizens United jurisprudence and instead focusing on changing state incorporation laws that the high court rarely meddles with.


	The measure's proponents note that Citizens United is predicated on state laws giving corporations the same powers as actual human beings, including the power to spend on politics. But they point out that in past eras, state laws granted corporations more limited powers ‚Äî and states never relinquished their authority to redefine what corporations can and cannot do. The Montana initiative proposes to simply use that authority to change the law ‚Äî in this case, to no longer grant corporations the power to spend on elections. 


	If passed in Montana ‚Äî and if other states follow ‚Äî the initiative could profoundly change American politics. Corporations could still conduct all their normal business, but they would no longer have the power to buy elections or legislation. What's more, state laws' existing anti-circumvention provisions ‚Äî which were recently upheld by the Supreme Court ‚Äî would deny those powers to out-of-state businesses, too. Though wealthy people would still retain their right to individually spend on politics, the new corporate codes would eliminate dark money groups, forcing oligarchs to emerge from anonymity and do their election spending through political committees requiring full disclosure. 


	To be sure, that still leaves the problem of billionaires using their outsized wealth to finance ad campaigns, demonize their opponents, amplify their puppets, and effectively control the election discourse. But here too the post-Citizens United world still permits a local solution: publicly financed campaigns that provide candidates with at least enough resources to make their voices heard.


	In 14 states and 26 cities of varying partisan complexion, governments offer qualifying candidates either grants or small-dollar matching funds. Unlike cash from private donors, this public money does not come with the quid-pro-quo expectation of legislative favors. Though the Supreme Court once attempted to limit the reach of these systems, the high court has never outlawed them ‚Äî in fact, justices explicitly declared ‚Äúwe do not today call into question the wisdom of public financing as a means of funding political candidacy.‚Äù

	











	These systems are no panacea ‚Äî they still let self-financed billionaire candidates and super PACs outspend publicly funded candidates. But for a relatively small investment of public money, more states and cities can create their own public financing systems that provide grassroots candidates enough resources to run competitive campaigns without having to succumb to legalized corruption and sell their future actions to prospective campaign contributors. 


	In a healthy republic, these straightforward initiatives would be on a glidepath. But at this dark hour for democracy, they face the daunting task of overcoming powerful interests profiting off the current system. They also face the formidable challenge of breaking through all the noise and convincing the country that corruption isn't an academic issue or a low-level concern ‚Äî it is the crisis creating every other problem.  


	‚ÄúCorruption is why they just defunded nursing homes to cut taxes for the rich,‚Äù Georgia's Democratic Sen. John Ossoff recently said. ‚ÄúCorruption is why you pay a fortune for prescriptions. Corruption is why your insurance claims keep getting denied. Corruption is why hedge funds get to buy up all the houses in your neighborhood driving you out of the market and then your corporate landlord ignores your calls during a gas leak. Corruption is why that ambulance cost $3,000 after you just had to get your choking toddler to the hospital.‚Äù 


	Of course, it is comforting to think we can just sit back and passively wait for this corruption nightmare to pass when the Trump presidency ends or if party control of Washington changes. That promise will likely be Democrats' message in 2026 and 2028. 


	But conservatives, their oligarch benefactors, and the Supreme Court clearly have a master plan to try to lock in the kleptocratic status quo. 


	They know that in a functioning one-person-one-vote democracy, they could never pass the unpopular self-enriching policies they want ‚Äî and so they know they must focus on preserving and expanding the precedents that permit them to buy American democracy.





	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					J.D. Vance Tried to Evade Journalists' Questions. It Did Not Go Well		
	









	
	
		
					What ‚ÄòMonster: The Ed Gein Story' Gets Right and Wrong		
	









	
	
		
					MAGA's Unhinged Reaction to Bad Bunny at the Super Bowl: What's Happened So Far		
	









	
	
		
					Trump Is Letting Qatar Build a Military Facility in the U.S. and MAGA Is Not Happy		
	









	They can still be stopped ‚Äî but only if we finally make anti-corruption the central focus of our politics.


The Lever's David Sirota and Jared Jacang Maher are the authors of Master Plan: The Hidden Plot to Legalize Corruption in America.

Title: Woody Allen Remembers Diane Keaton: 'a Million Laughs To Be Around'
Description:
By 

	Emily Zemler



Woody Allen, who regularly collaborated with Diane Keaton throughout her career, honored the actress following her death in a tribute published on The Free Press. The disgraced filmmaker shared his memories of Keaton, who appeared in movies like Annie Hall, Sleeper, Manhattan, and Love and Death. 


	‚ÄúUnlike anyone the planet has experienced or is unlikely to ever see again, her face and laugh illuminated any space she entered,‚Äù Allen wrote. ‚ÄúI first laid eyes on her lanky beauty at an audition and thought, If Huckleberry Finn was a gorgeous young woman, he'd be Keaton.‚Äù 


	Allen described working with Keaton over the years, but also being her longtime friend. He wrote that her opinion was one of the only ones he trusted. ‚ÄúAs time went on I made movies for an audience of one, Diane Keaton,‚Äù Allen wrote. ‚ÄúI never read a single review of my work and cared only what Keaton had to say about it. If she liked it, I counted the film as an artistic success. If she was less than enthusiastic, I tried to use her criticism to reedit and come away with something she felt better about.‚Äù

	











	He added, ‚ÄúShe had huge talent for comedies and drama, but she could also dance and sing with feeling. She also wrote books and did photography, made collages, decorated homes, and directed films. Finally, she was a million laughs to be around.‚Äù




			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	Allen and Keaton were one-time romantic partners and stayed friends in the years after. He wrote numerous roles specifically for her to play, including the titular character in 1977's Annie Hall, for which she won Best Actress. Many speculated that the film was based on their prior relationship, although Keaton told The New York Times, ‚ÄúIt's not true, but there are elements of truth in it.‚Äù

	











	He noted of her style, ‚ÄúHer fashion sense was a sight to behold, of course. Her sartorial concoctions rivaled the contraptions of Rube Goldberg. She put together clothing that defied logic but always worked. In later years, her look became more elegant.‚Äù





	
		Editor's picks
	
	











	
	
		
					The 250 Greatest Albums of the 21st Century So Far		
	














	
	
		
					The 100 Best TV Episodes of All Time		
	









	In the tribute, Allen described his romantic relationship with Keaton, including recalling meeting her family. ‚ÄúThis was Keaton's world, her people, her background,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúIt was amazing that this beautiful yokel went on to become an award-winning actress and sophisticated fashion icon. We had a few great personal years together and finally we both moved on, and why we parted only God and Freud might be able to figure out.‚Äù


	‚ÄúShe went on to date a number of exciting men, all of them more fascinating than I was,‚Äù Allen continued. ‚ÄúI went on to keep trying to make that great masterpiece that I am still struggling with when I last looked. I kidded Keaton that we'd wind up ‚Äî she like Norma Desmond, me like Erich von Stroheim, once her director, now her chauffeur. But the world is constantly being redefined, and with Keaton's passing it is redefined once again. A few days ago the world was a place that included Diane Keaton. Now it's a world that does not. Hence, it's a drearier world. Still, there are her movies. And her great laugh still echoes in my head.‚Äù


	Allen has dogged controversy since having an affair with his partner Mia Farrow's adopted daughter Soon-Yi Previn. During his custody battle with Farrow, she claimed Allen had ‚Äúacted inappropriately‚Äù with her daughter, Dylan Farrow. Allen denied the accusations and married Previn, who he has been with for more than 20 years. The claims resurfaced during the #MeToo movement and Keaton took to social media to defend Allen. 


	‚ÄúWoody Allen is my friend and I continue to believe him,‚Äù Keaton wrote. ‚ÄúIt might be of interest to take a look at the 60 Minute interview from 1992 and see what you think.‚Äù





	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					J.D. Vance Tried to Evade Journalists' Questions. It Did Not Go Well		
	









	
	
		
					What ‚ÄòMonster: The Ed Gein Story' Gets Right and Wrong		
	









	
	
		
					MAGA's Unhinged Reaction to Bad Bunny at the Super Bowl: What's Happened So Far		
	









	
	
		
					Trump Is Letting Qatar Build a Military Facility in the U.S. and MAGA Is Not Happy		
	









	In 2017, Allen made a rare appearance to present Keaton with the AFI Life Achievement Award. ‚ÄúThe minute I met her, she was a great, great inspiration to me,‚Äù Allen said during the event. ‚ÄúMuch of what I've accomplished in my life I owe, for sure, to her. Seeing life through her eyes. She really is astonishing. This is a woman who is great at everything she does.‚Äù
